How I use Evernote: Capturing information

May 30, 2013

Evernote is the most versatile tool in my digital toolbox. I use it for, what seems like, everything. I’ve
heard their CEO say many times that their desire is for the service to be a 'second brain’ for their users. If I am any indication, they are well on their way.

Why am I taking the time to write a post about a product that I have no financial stake in? Two reasons: First, I love it. I genuinely do. I am a big fan of the service and the company. They do things right, and I really appreciate that.

Second, late last week I posted a piece on the blog detailing my social media workflow. While it did not exactly crash the Internet, it generated some good discussion in the comments. Several of the commenters indicated that they wanted more information on how I use Evernote. I like to think deeply about how I do what I do, so it sounded like a really good topic to explore.

In this post I will cover the basics of how I use Evernote and the specifics of how I capture notes. In part two, I will show you how I organize my Evernote account. Then finally in part three, I will discuss the applications I use with Evernote.

What is Evernote?

First, how about short
introduction for those of you unfamiliar with the service and applications?
Evernote is, at it’s core, a note taking application. It gives you the ability
to take a note on almost any device and then access it from any other device.
This may sound very basic, and not much like a second brain, but that is
because what the company has done is take this very simple idea and give it
wide-ranging power. From powerful search, tagging, location, image search and
integration features, to their near-ubiquity on modern PC and device operating
systems, Evernote gives its users the ability to remember everything they need,
and more.

How do I use it?

I have learned one clear thing
in collaborating with and talking to other Evernote users: everyone has a
different viewpoint on how to use it. It can be used in many different ways.
That is the power of the service. What I detail in this series of posts is
simply how I use the tools. It may not work for you, but I hope you can pick up
something valuable.

I work for a large IT solutions company with an
appropriately strict IT security policy. As a result I do not use Evernote for
work. I do not store company data in it; so my use of Evernote focuses on my personal
life and side projects, of which there are many.

I use Evernote to:

  • Archive travel and event information
  • Collect and manage recipes
  • Collect and review articles, tips and ideas for
    my writing projects before they start
  • Record interviews for my work with the Story
    Team
  • Take notes, make and use flashcards, and collect
    materials for my work towards an advanced theology degree
  • Contact information for networking and
    acquaintances

As you can see, I use it for
several different, specific goals. Your mileage will vary.

Information capture (it’s more than just note-taking)

Between all of the use cases I outlined above I use a
variety of tools to capture data in Evernote.

For information on the web
(travel & event info, recipes, articles and project research), I use the
Evernote Web Clipper extensively. It may be the leading tool I use to capture
data. The clipper is offered for all major browsers as an extension, and there
is a bookmarklet for other browsers. I also use the option in Chrome for the
clipper to search my Evernote note account when I do a Google search. This is a
really useful, and little talked about, feature. Also, when reading long form
articles I will use the Evernote Clearly Chrome extension for readability and
to import the content into Evernote. It’s a handy little extension.

In my theology classes this
past year I occasionally used Skitch to capture diagrams and visual aids, but
usually I did not have time while note taking to do it well. As a result, it
was little used. For design collaboration it can be a great tool, but I do not
rely on it heavily.

I use the Evernote Mac and
Windows apps for long form note taking. Whether it is in class, in meetings at
church or just at home gathering information for a project, I use the PC apps
extensively. I also use these apps exclusively for organizing my notes. I am
careful about how I process data in Evernote, but more about that in my next
post.

For contact information I use
Evernote Hello for iOS. I will go into this app in more detail in a later post.
It is a great app for managing contacts in Evernote, and for keeping my
networking and acquaintance information out of my iPhone contacts list (which
is already overcrowded).

For recording interviews for
Story Team assignments I use both the Mac and iPhone apps. After a mishap with
my phone during an interview a few years ago I have started using a backup. I
capture the primary recording on my Mac via recording software and a Samson USB
Go Mic. After the interview I edit the start and finish, export to an mp3 and
then import it into Evernote. While the Evernote client can record it directly,
I like the control and options I have with this workflow. As a backup I also
record the interview on my iPhone, directly into the Evernote app. Using this
process I get clean audio and have not lost another interview.

Finally, I use the iOS app to
capture all physical paperwork. The image capture tools in the apps, and OCS on
the Evernote servers make this a completely valid option. In fact, I have
considered getting a scanner that can capture directly into the Evernote app, but
the quality of the image capture and text recognition fully satisfy my
requirements.

Next time on the blog

In my next post I will address
my process and organization techniques, and then I will cover apps in my final
post of the series.

I hope this has been a helpful
post for Evernote users, or those considering picking it up. I’m not the only
user out there, and I am sure my readers have additional insight. How do you
capture information in Evernote? Is there a cool tool out there I’m not aware
of? Share it with us in the comments below!
